title: A が いちばん～ (A ga ichiban～)
short_explanation: Express the superlative degree; 'the most', 'the best', 'the least'.
long_explanation: The A が いちばん～ grammar point is used to express a superlative degree or the highest rank. It can be translated as 'the most', 'the best', or 'the least' in English. The formation is used with various adjectives and verbs, and can also be used in comparison with other items or people.
formation: Noun + が + いちばん + Adjective/Verb

examples.jp: この中で、寿司が一番好きです。
examples.romaji: Kono naka de, sushi ga ichiban suki desu.
examples.en: Of all these, I like sushi the most.
examples.grammar_audio: /audio/japanese/grammar/s_A_が_いちばん～_A_ga_ichiban～_20250209_この中で寿司が一番好きです.mp3

examples.jp: 彼女はクラスで一番速く泳げます。
examples.romaji: Kanojo wa kurasu de ichiban hayaku oyogemasu.
examples.en: She can swim the fastest in the class.
examples.grammar_audio: /audio/japanese/grammar/s_A_が_いちばん～_A_ga_ichiban～_20250209_彼女はクラスで一番速く泳げます.mp3

examples.jp: この町では、この公園が一番きれいです。
examples.romaji: Kono machi de wa, kono kouen ga ichiban kirei desu.
examples.en: In this town, this park is the most beautiful.
examples.grammar_audio: /audio/japanese/grammar/s_A_が_いちばん～_A_ga_ichiban～_20250209_この町ではこの公園が一番きれいです.mp3

examples.romaji: Nomimono no naka de wa, koucha ga ichiban suki desu.
examples.en: Among all drinks, I like tea the most.

title: A。けれども、～B。(A. Keredomo,~ B.)
short_explanation: Used to express a contrast between two statements. It can be translated as 'but' or 'however'.
long_explanation: The grammar point A。けれども、～B。 is used to express a contrast or contradiction between statement A and statement B. It can be translated as 'but' or 'however' in English. けれども is a conjunction that links two clauses to show there is a conflicting or opposing idea between them.
formation: Statement A + けれども、+ Statement B

examples.jp: 今日は晴れている。けれども、寒いです。
examples.romaji: Kyou wa harete iru. Keredo mo, samui desu.
examples.en: It is sunny today. However, it is cold.
examples.grammar_audio: /audio/japanese/grammar/s_Aけれども～BA_Keredomo_B_20250209_今日は晴れているけれども寒いです.mp3

examples.jp: 彼女はうるさい。けれども、面白いです。
examples.romaji: Kanojo wa urusai. Keredo mo, omoshiroi desu.
examples.en: She is noisy. But, she is interesting.
examples.grammar_audio: /audio/japanese/grammar/s_Aけれども～BA_Keredomo_B_20250209_彼女はうるさいけれども面白いです.mp3

examples.jp: その映画は長かった。けれども、退屈じゃなかった。
examples.romaji: Sono eiga wa nagakatta. Keredo mo, taikutsu janakatta.
examples.en: The movie was long. But, it wasn't boring.
examples.grammar_audio: /audio/japanese/grammar/s_Aけれども～BA_Keredomo_B_20250209_その映画は長かったけれども退屈じゃなかった.mp3

examples.jp: 彼は運動が得意だ。けれども、勉強は苦手だ。
examples.romaji: Kare wa undou ga tokui da. Keredo mo, benkyou wa nigate da.
examples.en: He is good at sports. However, he is not good at studying.

title: A。しかし、～B。 (A. Shikashi, ~B.)
short_explanation: Expresses contrast or contradiction between two clauses; 'A, but B', 'A, however B'.
long_explanation: The grammar point A。しかし、～B。 is used to show contrast or contradiction between two clauses. It can be translated as 'A, but B' or 'A, however B' in English. しかし is placed between two sentences to indicate a contrast between them.
formation: Sentence A + しかし + Sentence B.

examples.jp: 今日は忙しい。しかし、時間があるなら、コーヒーを飲もう。
examples.romaji: Kyou wa isogashii. Shikashi, jikan ga aru nara, koohii o nomou.
examples.en: I'm busy today. However, if I have time, let's have coffee.

examples.jp: 彼は疲れていた。しかし、宿題を終わらせた。
examples.romaji: Kare wa tsukareteita. Shikashi, shukudai o owaraseta.
examples.en: He was tired. However, he finished his homework.

examples.jp: 部屋は狭いです。しかし、便利な場所にあります。

title: A。じゃ、～B。(A. Ja, ~B.)
short_explanation: Indicates a decision or suggestion; 'well then', 'in that case', 'so'.
long_explanation: The A。じゃ、～B。grammar point is used to express a decision, suggestion, or course of action based on a given situation or information. It can be translated as 'well then', 'in that case', or 'so' in English. This grammar works with any form of sentence, whether it's a verb, noun, い-adjective, or な-adjective in both parts (A and B).
formation: A: Sentence, B: Sentence (A and B can be any sentence type)

examples.jp: 映画は時間がない。じゃ、また今度行こう。
examples.romaji: Eiga wa jikan ga nai. Ja, mata kondo ikou.
examples.en: There's no time for a movie. Well then, let's go another time.
examples.grammar_audio: /audio/japanese/grammar/s_Aじゃ～BA_Ja_B_20250209_映画は時間がないじゃまた今度行こう.mp3

examples.jp: お腹がすいた。じゃ、レストランに行こう。
examples.romaji: Onaka ga suita. Ja, resutoran ni ikou.
examples.en: I'm hungry. In that case, let's go to a restaurant.
examples.grammar_audio: /audio/japanese/grammar/s_Aじゃ～BA_Ja_B_20250209_お腹がすいたじゃレストランに行こう.mp3

examples.jp: 電車が遅れた。じゃ、バスで行こう。
examples.romaji: Densha ga okureta. Ja, basu de ikou.
examples.en: The train is late. So, let's go by bus.
examples.grammar_audio: /audio/japanese/grammar/s_Aじゃ～BA_Ja_B_20250209_電車が遅れたじゃバスで行こう.mp3

examples.jp: このシャツは高い。じゃ、別のを買おう。
examples.romaji: Kono shatsu wa takai. Ja, betsu no o kau.
examples.en: This shirt is expensive. Well then, let's buy a different one.
examples.grammar_audio: /audio/japanese/grammar/s_Aじゃ～BA_Ja_B_20250209_このシャツは高いじゃ別のを買おう.mp3

title: A。それじゃ、～B。(A. Soreja,~B.)
short_explanation: Connect two sentences; 'A, so/in that case, B'
long_explanation: The A。それじゃ、～B。grammar point is used to connect two sentences or ideas. It translates to 'A, so/in that case, B' in English. This expression is used when the first sentence (A) creates a situation or context and the second sentence (B) indicates the consequence or response to that situation.
formation: Sentence A + 。それじゃ、 + Sentence B

examples.jp: 今日は休みです。それじゃ、映画を観に行きましょう。
examples.romaji: Kyou wa yasumi desu. Soreja, eiga wo mi ni ikimashou.
examples.en: Today is a day off. In that case, let's go watch a movie.

examples.jp: 電気が切れた。それじゃ、ろうそくを使いましょう。
examples.romaji: Denki ga kireta. Soreja, rousoku wo tsukaimashou.
examples.en: The electricity went out. In that case, let's use candles.
examples.grammar_audio: /audio/japanese/grammar/s_Aそれじゃ～BA_SorejaB_20250209_電気が切れたそれじゃろうそくを使いましょう.mp3

examples.jp: レストランが混んでいます。それじゃ、別の場所で食べましょう。
examples.romaji: Resutoran ga kondeimasu. Soreja, betsu no basho de tabemashou.
examples.en: The restaurant is crowded. In that case, let's eat somewhere else.

examples.jp: 明日は雨が降るらしい。それじゃ、ピクニックは中止しましょう。
examples.romaji: Ashita wa ame ga furu rashii. Soreja, pikunikku wa chuushi shimashou.
examples.en: It seems it will rain tomorrow. In that case, let's cancel the picnic.

title: A。それでは、～B。(A. Soredewa,~B.)
short_explanation: Express a change in situation; 'then', 'in that case', 'so'.
long_explanation: The A。それでは、～B。grammar point is used to express a change in situation or transition from one action to another. It can be translated as 'then', 'in that case', or 'so' in English. The formation consists of two sentences or clauses, with それでは connecting them and reflecting a change based on the previous statement (A).
formation: A (Statement) + 。それでは、 + B (Follow-up action or statement)

examples.jp: 今日は休みだ。それでは、映画を見に行こう。
examples.romaji: Kyou wa yasumi da. Sore dewa, eiga wo mi ni ikou.
examples.en: Today is a day off. In that case, let's go see a movie.
examples.grammar_audio: /audio/japanese/grammar/s_Aそれでは～BA_SoredewaB_20250209_今日は休みだそれでは映画を見に行こう.mp3

examples.romaji: Kono pan wa mou furui desu. Sore dewa, sutemashou.
examples.en: This bread is already old. Then, let's throw it away.

examples.jp: 雨が降ってきた。それでは、室内で遊ぼう。
examples.romaji: Ame ga futtekita. Sore dewa, shitsunai de asobou.
examples.en: It started raining. In that case, let's play indoors.
examples.grammar_audio: /audio/japanese/grammar/s_Aそれでは～BA_SoredewaB_20250209_雨が降ってきたそれでは室内で遊ぼう.mp3

examples.jp: お腹が空いた。それでは、何か食べに行きましょう。
examples.romaji: Onaka ga suita. Sore dewa, nani ka tabe ni ikimashou.
examples.en: I'm hungry. So, let's go eat something.
examples.grammar_audio: /audio/japanese/grammar/s_Aそれでは～BA_SoredewaB_20250209_お腹が空いたそれでは何か食べに行きましょう.mp3

title: A。 では、～B。 (A. Dewa, ~B)
short_explanation: Indicates a contrast or comparison between A and B; 'As for A, ~B'.
long_explanation: The A では、～B grammar point is used to indicate a contrast or comparison between A and B. It is used to express that 'As for A, ~ B' or 'Regarding A, ~ B'. This grammar structure is often used for contrasting or comparing different subjects/topics.
formation: Noun A + では、 + Subject + Predicate B

examples.jp: 果物では、リンゴが一番好きです。
examples.romaji: Kudamono dewa, ringo ga ichiban suki desu.
examples.en: As for fruits, apples are my favorite.

examples.romaji: Supōtsu dewa, sakkā ga ichiban ninki desu.

examples.jp: 今日の天気では、雨が降りそうです。
examples.romaji: Kyou no tenki dewa, ame ga furisou desu.
examples.en: As for today's weather, it looks like it will rain.

title: A。でも、～B。(A. Demo, ~B)
short_explanation: Used to express contrast between two statements; 'A, but B', 'A, however B'.
long_explanation: The A。でも、～B。grammar point is used to express contrast or an unexpected continuation from statement A to statement B. It can be translated as 'A, but B' or 'A, however B' in English. The formation simply places でも at the beginning of the second sentence to show contrast with the first sentence.
formation: Clause A + でも + Clause B

examples.jp: 昨日は寒かった。でも、今日は暖かいです。
examples.romaji: Kinou wa samukatta. Demo, kyou wa atatakai desu.
examples.en: Yesterday was cold. But today it's warm.

title: Aと Bと どちら～ (A to B to dochira~)
short_explanation: Used to ask which of two alternatives is preferred or to compare two things
long_explanation: The grammar pattern Aと Bと どちら～ is used to compare two alternatives A and B, and ask which one is preferred, better, or more suitable. It can be used with verbs, adjectives, or nouns.
formation: Aと Bと どちら + Verb/Adjective/Noun

examples.romaji: Ringo to mikan to dochira ga suki desu ka?

title: AとBと どっち〜 (A to B to docchi〜)
short_explanation: Asking which one; 'which', 'A or B'.
long_explanation: The  AとBと どっち〜 grammar point is used to ask which one to choose between two options, A and B. It can be translated as 'which', 'A or B' in English. This is often used in casual speech and can be shortened to  AかBか どっち〜.
formation: AとBと どっち + Verb, AかBか どっち + Verb

title: A は B が〜 (A wa B ga〜)
short_explanation: Indicates that there is something unique or different about A and describes what is special about it.
long_explanation: The A は B が〜 grammar point is used to emphasize the uniqueness or difference of 'A' by describing a characteristic or feature 'B' that is specific to 'A'. This structure is used to convey that there is something notable or special about 'A' when compared to others.
formation: A は (Topic) + B が (Characteristic/Feature) + Description/Action

title: A は B より～ (A wa B yori～)
short_explanation: Express a comparison between A and B; 'A is more/less than B'.
long_explanation: The A は B より grammar point is used to express a comparison between two items or subjects (A and B). It can be translated as 'A is more/less than B' in English. This structure is followed by an adjective that describes the comparison.
formation: A は B より + Adjective

examples.en: This juice is sweeter than that juice.

title: A より B のほうが～ (A yori B no hou ga ～)
short_explanation: Used to compare two items; 'B is more ～ than A'.
long_explanation: The grammar point A より B のほうが～ is used to compare two items or situations and indicate that one is more (adjective) than the other. It can be translated as 'B is more ～ than A' in English. It is used with both い-adjectives and な-adjectives.
formation: A + より + B + のほうが + Adjective

title: い-Adjective く + Verb (i-Adjective + ku + Verb)
short_explanation: Used to connect an い-adjective to a verb, modifying the verb (adverbial usage).
long_explanation: The い-Adjective + く + Verb grammar point transforms an い-adjective into its adverbial form, describing how the verb is performed. In English, this often corresponds to '-ly' adverbs (e.g., 'quickly', 'slowly').
formation: い-Adjective (remove い) + く + Verb

title: い-Adjective く します (i-Adjective ku shimasu)
short_explanation: Use an い-adjective to express 'to make' or 'to become'.
long_explanation: By adding くします to an い-adjective, you express making something (or causing something to become) the quality of that adjective. In English, this often corresponds to phrases like 'make something more ADJECTIVE.'
formation: い-Adjective (remove い) + くします

examples.jp: 部屋を明るくします。
examples.romaji: Heya o akaruku shimasu.
examples.en: I will make the room brighter.

examples.romaji: Tomodachi no kibun o tanoshiku shimasu.

title: い-Adjective: Negative Polite Form
short_explanation: Change an い-adjective into a polite negative form with ～くないです (or ～くありません).
long_explanation: To make an い-adjective negative and polite, remove the final い and add くないです. An alternative more formal style is くありません. For example, 美味しい → 美味しくないです / 美味しくありません。
formation: い-Adjective (remove い) + くないです

title: い-Adjective て (i-Adjective + te~)
short_explanation: Used to connect two or more い-adjectives to describe something.
long_explanation: The い-Adjective て form is used to connect two or more い-adjectives when listing attributes of something or someone. To form it, replace the final い with くて. For example, かわいい → かわいくて, おいしい → おいしくて.
formation: い-Adjective (remove い) + くて + い-Adjective

examples.jp: このリンゴは甘くて美味しいです。
examples.romaji: Kono ringo wa amakute oishii desu.

title: な-Adjective に + Verb
short_explanation: Turn a な-adjective into an adverb by adding に.
long_explanation: To make a な-adjective modify a verb, remove the な and add に. This form describes how an action is performed. For instance, 静か（な） → 静かに, 親切（な） → 親切に.
formation: な-Adjective (remove な) + に + Verb

title: な-Adjective で～ (na-Adjective de~)
short_explanation: Usage of で to connect or add information with a な-adjective.
long_explanation: Use な-adjective + で to connect it to another quality, action, or description. It can combine a な-adjective with another adjective, verb, or clause.
formation: な-Adjective + で

long_explanation: The な-adjective に します pattern is used to express a decision or choice based on a な-adjective. It often translates as 'I’ll make it ...,' 'I will choose ...,' or 'I’ve decided on ...'.
formation: な-Adjective + に + します

long_explanation: The な-Adjective + に + なります grammar point is used to express a change or transformation into the state described by the な-adjective. It translates to 'become' or 'turn into' along with the meaning of the な-adjective.

title: Noun か Noun か～ (Noun ka Noun ka～)
short_explanation: Expresses choice or alternatives; 'either', 'or'.
long_explanation: The Noun か Noun か～ grammar point is used to present two or more alternatives for a choice. It can be translated to 'either', 'or' in English. It is formed by placing the particle か in between two nouns or noun phrases.

title: Noun が できます (Noun ga dekimasu)
short_explanation: Express the ability to do something.
long_explanation: The Noun が できます grammar point is used to express the ability to do something. In this grammar pattern, the noun is the activity that the speaker or subject can do. It translates as 'can do' or 'able to do' in English.

formation: Noun + が + ほしいです

title: Noun くらい～ (Noun kurai～)
short_explanation: Express the extent or degree of something; 'about', 'approximately', 'at least'.
long_explanation: The くらい grammar point is used with a noun to express the extent or degree of something, meaning 'about', 'approximately', or 'at least' in English. It helps to provide a rough estimate or minimum standard to the noun it is attached to.

title: Noun ぐらい～ (Noun gurai～)
short_explanation: Express an approximate amount or degree; 'about', 'approximately'.
long_explanation: The ぐらい grammar point is used with nouns to express an approximate amount or degree. It is often translated as 'about', 'approximately', or 'around' in English. This can be used for time, quantity, or other measurements.
formation: Noun + ぐらい

examples.jp: 一日中勉強したので、１０時間ぐらい勉強しました。

examples.en: I studied all day, so I studied for about 10 hours.

title: Noun ごろ～ (Noun + goro～)
short_explanation: Expresses 'around' or 'about' a certain time or age.
long_explanation: The ごろ grammar point is used to indicate 'around' or 'about' a certain time or age. It is commonly used with time-related expressions and age-related expressions to give an approximate time or age.
formation: Noun + ごろ

examples.jp: 昼ごろに電話してください。
examples.romaji: Hiru goro ni denwa shite kudasai.
examples.en: Please call me around noon.

title: Noun だけ〜 (〜dake)
short_explanation: Indicates 'only', 'just', or 'merely'.
long_explanation: The Noun だけ grammar point is used to emphasize the idea of 'only', 'just', or 'merely' in a sentence. It can be attached to nouns, verbs, い-adjectives, and な-adjectives to show this emphasis. This grammar point is commonly used in both spoken and written Japanese.
formation: Noun + だけ, Verb-casual + だけ, い-Adjective + だけ, な-Adjective-な + だけ

examples.jp: コーヒーだけ飲んで、帰りました。
examples.romaji: Koohii dake nonde, kaerimashita.
examples.en: I only drank coffee and went home.
examples.grammar_audio: /audio/japanese/grammar/s_Noun_だけ_dake_20250209_コーヒーだけ飲んで帰りました.mp3

examples.jp: この本は二十ページだけ読んだ。
examples.romaji: Kono hon wa nijuu peeji dake yonda.
examples.en: I only read twenty pages of this book.
examples.grammar_audio: /audio/japanese/grammar/s_Noun_だけ_dake_20250209_この本は二十ページだけ読んだ.mp3

examples.jp: 彼女はとても速いですが、走るだけでなく、考えるのも速いです。
examples.romaji: Kanojo wa totemo hayai desu ga, hashiru dake denaku, kangaeru no mo hayai desu.

title: Nounで～ (Noun de ~)
short_explanation: Indicate a place or means for an action or situation; 'at, in, on', 'using', or 'by means of'.
long_explanation: The で grammar point is used to indicate a location, method, or tool for doing an action or for being in a situation. It can be translated as 'at, in, on', 'using', or 'by means of' in English. Nounで is formed by adding で after a noun.
formation: Noun + で

examples.jp: 図書館で勉強します。
examples.romaji: Toshokan de benkyou shimasu.
examples.en: I study at the library.

examples.jp: バスで学校に行きます。

title: Noun と～ (Noun to～)
short_explanation: Express 'with', 'and' or 'together with' when connecting nouns.
long_explanation: The Noun と grammar point is used to express a connection between two or more nouns, indicating 'with', 'and', or 'together with' in English. It functions as a particle that is used to simply list multiple items or express companionship.
formation: Noun1 + と + Noun2

examples.jp: リンゴとバナナを買いました。
examples.romaji: Ringo to banana wo kaimashita.
examples.en: I bought apples and bananas.

examples.jp: 友達と映画を見に行きます。

title: Noun に～ (Noun ni～)
short_explanation: Express a specific direction, target or purpose; 'to', 'toward', 'for'.
long_explanation: The 'Noun に' grammar point is used to express a specific direction, target, or purpose in relation to a noun. It can be translated as 'to', 'toward', or 'for' in English. The に particle is added directly after the noun which indicates direction, target or purpose.
formation: Noun + に

examples.jp: 彼女にプレゼントをあげました。
examples.romaji: Kanojo ni purezento wo agemashita.
examples.en: I gave a present to her.

title: Noun に 帰ります (Noun ni kaerimasu)
short_explanation: Express going back or returning to a place: 'to return to', 'to go back to'.
long_explanation: The grammar point 'Noun に 帰ります' is used to express physically going back or returning to a specific place. It can be translated as 'to go back to' or 'to return to' in English. The particle に indicates the destination of the return.
formation: Noun + に + 帰ります

examples.jp: 夏休みが終わったら、学校に帰ります。
examples.romaji: Natsuyasumi ga owattara, gakkou ni kaerimasu.

title: Noun に します (Noun ni shimasu)
short_explanation: Express a choice or decision; 'choose', 'decide on'.
long_explanation: The に します grammar point is used to express making a choice or decision. It can be translated as 'choose' or 'decide on' in English. It is often used in situations where someone has to make a selection or decide on something, such as ordering food at a restaurant or deciding on a vacation destination.
formation: Noun + に します

examples.jp: 今日の昼ご飯は寿司にします。
examples.romaji: Kyou no hirugohan wa sushi ni shimasu.
examples.en: I'll choose sushi for today's lunch.

examples.romaji: Kono kutsu wo kau ka mayotteimasu ga, akai iro no hou ni shimasu.
examples.en: I was hesitating about which shoes to buy, but I'll go with the red ones.

title: Noun に なります (Noun ni narimasu)
short_explanation: Expresses change or becoming something; 'to become', 'to turn into', 'to be'.
long_explanation: The grammar point Noun に なります is used to express a change or transformation into something else, or to indicate that something 'becomes', 'turns into', or simply 'is' something. It is commonly used with nouns.
formation: Noun + に + なります

examples.jp: 彼は医者になります。
examples.romaji: Kare wa isha ni narimasu.
examples.en: He will become a doctor.

title: Noun に 来ます (Noun ni kimasu)
short_explanation: Used to express coming to a place.
long_explanation: The grammar point Noun に 来ます is used to indicate that someone or something comes to a specific place. The noun before に indicates the destination or place, while the verb 来ます expresses the action of coming. (Similarly, 'Noun に 行きます' means 'go to [Noun],' and 'Noun に 帰ります' means 'return to [Noun].')
formation: Noun + に + 来ます (kimasu)

title: Noun に 行きます (Noun ni ikimasu)
short_explanation: Used to express going to a location.
long_explanation: The Noun に 行きます grammar point is used to express going to a specific location. This structure requires a noun (indicating the destination) followed by に and the verb 行きます, which means 'to go'.
formation: Noun + に + 行きます

title: Noun の あとで (Noun no atode)
short_explanation: Expresses the order of events; 'after', 'later than'.
long_explanation: The の あとで grammar point is used to express the order of events, specifying that an action occurs after or later than the noun mentioned. It translates to 'after' or 'later than' in English. This structure is simply formed by attaching の あとで to the noun.
formation: Noun + の + あとで

long_explanation: The grammar point Noun の 前に is used to describe a location or position 'in front of' a noun. It is formed by adding の 前に after the noun it refers to. (Note that 'Noun の 前に' can also mean 'before [Noun]' in time contexts, but these examples focus on physical location.)

title: Noun は～ (Noun wa〜)
short_explanation: Used to mark the topic of a sentence; 'as for', 'speaking of'.
long_explanation: The は (wa) particle is used to indicate the topic of a sentence. It is usually translated as 'as for', 'speaking of', or it simply marks what the sentence is about. This is different from が (ga), which marks the subject of a verb.
formation: Noun + は

title: Noun も〜 (Noun mo~)
short_explanation: Indicates that the action or state is the same for multiple items or people; 'also', 'as well'.
long_explanation: The も grammar point is used after a noun to indicate that the action or state is the same for multiple items or people. It means 'also', 'as well', or 'too' in English. も often replaces は or が in the sentence to show that the same statement applies to this additional noun.
formation: Noun + も

title: Noun や Noun など～ (Noun ya Noun nado)
short_explanation: Lists items or examples but not exhaustively; 'such as', 'like', 'and so on'.
long_explanation: The や...など grammar point is used to list a few items or examples that belong to a similar category or context, but it is not exhaustive. It can be translated as 'such as', 'like', or 'and so on' in English. This grammar pattern is used with nouns.

title: Noun を〜 (Noun wo〜)
short_explanation: Indicates the direct object of a verb.
long_explanation: The を (wo) particle is used to mark the direct object of a verb in a sentence. It shows the noun that the action (verb) is performed on. The particle を is usually pronounced as 'o' in spoken Japanese.

title: Verb た あとで (ta ato de)
short_explanation: Indicates an action that takes place after another action.
long_explanation: The たあとで grammar point is used to indicate that one action takes place after another action is completed. It means 'after' or 'after doing' in English. The formation is created with the た form (past tense) of a verb, followed by あとで (ato de).
formation: Verb-た form + あとで

title: Verb たいです (taidesu)
short_explanation: Express desire or want to do something; 'I want to', 'I would like to'.
long_explanation: The たいです grammar point is used to express the speaker's desire or want to perform a certain action. It can be translated as 'I want to' or 'I would like to' in English. The formation differs depending on whether the verb is a る-verb or an う-verb.
formation: る-Verb: Remove る and add たいです, う-Verb: Replace the final verb character with the ～い form and add たいです, Exception: する becomes したいです

title: Verb て～ (Verb + te～)
short_explanation: A verb conjugation that connects actions or states.
long_explanation: The ～て form of a verb is used to connect actions or states in a sequence, implying that the first action is completed before the second one starts. The ～て form is frequently used in casual speech, and it can also be used in polite speech when combined with certain auxiliary verbs like ください (kudasai) or いる (iru).
formation: Verb (Group 1) - Replace last syllable with 〜て, Verb (Group 2) - Replace 'る' with 〜て, Verb (Group 3) - する becomes して, くる becomes きて

long_explanation: The て います grammar point is used to express an action that is ongoing, continuous, or has been happening. It is formed by conjugating the verb in its て-form and adding います. It can be translated as 'is doing', 'is doing (continuous)', or 'has been doing' in English.

long_explanation: The ～てから grammar point is used to indicate the sequence of actions or events, meaning that one action or event occurs after another. It can be translated as 'after', 'since', or 'once' in English. The て-form indicates the first action and から shows the sequence.

long_explanation: The grammar point Verb に きます is used to express the purpose of coming to a place to perform an action. It can be translated as 'come to (do something)' in English. To form this expression, use the verb's ます-stem (i.e., remove ます) followed by に きます.

long_explanation: The grammar point いつか is used to indicate an unspecified point in time, meaning 'someday', 'one day', or 'at some point' in the future or the past. It can be used in sentences to express hopes, dreams, or possibilities.

long_explanation: The ～から grammar point is used to indicate the reason or cause for something. It can be translated as 'because', 'since', or 'so' in English. The formation differs depending on whether it is used with a verb, い-adjective, な-adjective, or noun.
formation: Verb-casual + から / い-Adjective + から / な-Adjective + だから / Noun + だから

short_explanation: Refers to a short time ago or just now.
long_explanation: The word さっき (sakki) is an adverb used to express that something happened or was done a short time ago or just now. It can be combined with verbs or other phrases to convey that meaning.
formation: さっき + verb / さっき + phrase

title: すぐに～ (sugu ni～)
short_explanation: Immediately or right away; used to express promptness or quickness.
long_explanation: The すぐに～ grammar point is used to express an action happening immediately or right away. It often indicates promptness or quickness and can be used with both verbs and adjectives.
formation: すぐに + Verb/Adjective

examples.jp: 友達が来たら、すぐに電話をかけてください。

title: ぜんぜん～ (zenzen～)
short_explanation: Used to express 'not at all' or 'completely' in negative sentences.
long_explanation: The ぜんぜん grammar point is used to emphasize a negative statement and can be translated as 'not at all' or 'completely (in negative sense)'. It is commonly used with negative verbs or negative forms of adjectives, placed before the negative part.
formation: ぜんぜん + [Negative verb/adjective]

examples.jp: 彼はぜんぜん話さない。
examples.romaji: Kare wa zenzen hanasanai.
examples.en: He doesn't talk at all.

title: そして、～ (soshite、～)
short_explanation: Used to connect two sentences; 'and then', 'and'.
long_explanation: The そして grammar point is used to connect two sentences or ideas, expressing a sequence of events or actions. It is commonly translated to 'and then' or simply 'and' in English.
formation: Sentence 1 + そして + Sentence 2

examples.jp: 朝起きて、そして宿題をしました。
examples.romaji: Asa okite, soshite shukudai wo shimashita.
examples.en: I woke up in the morning and then did my homework.

examples.jp: コーヒーを飲んで、そして新聞を読みました。
examples.romaji: Koohii wo nonde, soshite shinbun wo yomimashita.
examples.en: I drank coffee and then read the newspaper.
examples.grammar_audio: /audio/japanese/grammar/s_そして～_soshite～_20250209_コーヒーを飲んでそして新聞を読みました.mp3

title: そちら～ (sochira～)
short_explanation: Indicates a direction or person in moderate distance; 'that way', 'that person'.
long_explanation: The そちら grammar point is used to refer to a direction or a person that is moderate distance from both the speaker and listener, often closer to the listener. It can be translated as 'that way', 'that person', or 'that side'. This is distinct from あちら, used for things far from both speaker and listener.
formation: そちら [alone] / そちら + の + Noun

examples.jp: そちらのレストランはどうですか？
examples.romaji: Sochira no resutoran wa dou desu ka?
examples.en: How is that restaurant over there?

title: それから、～ (sorekara、～)
short_explanation: Meaning 'after that', 'and then' or 'then', indicating sequence of events.
long_explanation: The それから grammar point is used to describe the sequence of events or actions, indicating that one action or event takes place after another. It can be translated as 'after that', 'and then', or 'then' in English. It can be used with verbs, adjectives, and nouns but should be placed between two clauses.
formation: Clause 1 + それから + Clause 2

examples.jp: コーヒーを飲んで、それから家を出ました。
examples.romaji: Koohii o nonde, sorekara ie o demashita.
examples.en: I drank coffee, and then I left the house.

title: だいたい〜 (daitai〜)
short_explanation: Expresses 'roughly', 'approximately', or 'almost'.
long_explanation: The だいたい〜 (daitai〜) grammar point is used to express a rough estimate or generalization, meaning 'roughly', 'approximately', or 'almost' in English. It can be used before numbers, amounts, or percentages to show that the value is not exact.
formation: だいたい + Number/Amount/Percentage

title: たいてい～ (taitei～)
short_explanation: Used for expressing 'usually', 'mostly', or 'generally'.
long_explanation: The たいてい grammar point is used to describe a situation that occurs frequently or under normal circumstances. It can be translated as 'usually', 'mostly', or 'generally' in English. It is often used with verbs, but can also be used with adjectives and nouns.
formation: たいてい + Verb/い-Adjective/な-Adjective/Noun

examples.jp: たいてい朝８時に起きます。
examples.romaji: Taitei asa hachi-ji ni okimasu.

title: だから、～ (dakara、～)
short_explanation: Expresses a reason or cause; 'because', 'so', 'therefore'.
long_explanation: The だから grammar point is used to connect two sentences and express a reason or cause for the second sentence. It is typically used with nouns or な-adjectives, and can be translated as 'because', 'so', or 'therefore' in English. For verbs/い-adjectives, the form is usually ～から (not だから).
formation: Noun + だから / な-Adjective + だから

examples.jp: 雨だから、傘を持って行きましょう。

title: ～たり、～たり します (〜tari, 〜tari shimasu)
short_explanation: Used to list multiple actions or states; 'do things like', 'and'.
long_explanation: The ～たり、～たり します grammar point is used to list multiple actions or states without fully enumerating them. It can imply that there are more items in the list and can be translated as 'do things like', 'and', 'among other things', or 'and so on' in English. It is formed by attaching たり to the casual past tense of the verb, followed by します.
formation: Verb-casual-past + たり + Verb-casual-past + たり + します

title: だれ～ (dare～)
short_explanation: Asking 'who' in a sentence, used to inquire about someone's identity or to clarify who is being referred to.
long_explanation: The だれ〜 grammar point is used to ask about the identity of someone in a sentence. It can be translated as 'who' or 'whom' in English. It is often used with the particle が, は, or を, but can also be combined with other particles depending on the context.
formation: だれ + appropriate particle (が, は or を)

long_explanation: The grammar point だれか〜 is used to suggest that something is done by, possessed by, or related to 'someone', usually when the actual person is unidentified or not important. It can be used with verbs, adjectives, or nouns.
formation: だれか + Verb, だれか + Adjective, だれか + Noun

title: だれでも～ (dare demo～)

long_explanation: The grammar point だれでも is used to emphasize that something applies to everyone or anyone, regardless of who they are. It can be translated as 'anyone', 'everyone', or 'no matter who' in English. It is used in sentences to show that a certain situation, characteristic, or condition applies to all people.
formation: だれでも + Verb/Adjective/Noun

short_explanation: Express that an action doesn't take place anywhere; 'nowhere', 'not anywhere'.
long_explanation: The どこへも + Verb ないです grammar point is used to express a situation where an action doesn't occur or isn't applicable anywhere. It emphasizes a strong sense of not performing the action anywhere. Keep in mind that only negative verbs can follow 'どこへも' in this construction.
formation: どこへも + Verb in negative form (ないです)

long_explanation: The grammar point どこへも is used to express the idea of 'nowhere' or 'not to any place'. It is combined with the negative form of a verb to indicate that the action does not happen to any place or destination.

title: どちら～ (dochira～)

long_explanation: The どちら grammar point is used to ask about two choices or options. It translates to 'which of the two' or simply 'which' in English. long_explanation: The word どなた is a polite version of the question word だれ (who). It is used when asking about someone's identity or when seeking information about an unknown person in a polite or formal context. It can be used in questions and sometimes with も to express 'no matter who'.

title: なんでも～ (nandemo～)

long_explanation: The なんでも grammar point is used to express the concept of 'any', 'anything', or 'anyone' in Japanese. It can be used with verbs, adjectives, and nouns. It is often used in the meaning of 'no matter what' or 'regardless of'.

long_explanation: The ～に あげます grammar point is used when the speaker offers or gives something to someone. It emphasizes that the action is performed for the benefit of the receiver. The formation involves using the particle 'に' after the person receiving the item, followed by the verb あげます.

title: よく～ (yoku ~)
short_explanation: Often used to express 'doing something well' or 'often'.
long_explanation: The よく～ grammar point is used to express that someone does something well, frequently, or often. It is often placed before the verb and can also mean 'well done' or 'good job' when praising someone's action.
formation: よく + Verb-casual

examples.romaji: Kare wa yoku benkyou shimasu.
examples.en: He studies often.

title: ～（場所）に～があります (〜basho ni 〜 ga arimasu)
short_explanation: Express the existence or presence of something in a place.
long_explanation: The ～（場所）に～があります grammar point is used to express the existence or presence of something in a specific location. In this structure, the place is followed by 'に', then the object, plus が, and finally あります (to exist / there is).
formation: Place + に + Object/Thing + が + あります

examples.romaji: Toshokan ni takusan no hon ga arimasu.
examples.en: There are many books in the library.
